History_of_Present_Illness: Patient reports 'leg pain' which she describes as 'normal' and 'simple'.
Pain started this morning after waking up.
Patient denies any associated swelling, bruising, numbness, or tingling.
Patient denies any fall, hit, or accident as the cause of the pain.

Review_of_Systems.Musculoskeletal: Leg pain while walking, denies swelling, bruising, numbness, or tingling.

Objective.Observations_from_Transcript: Patient explicitly denies visible swelling or bruising. Patient denies numbness or tingling.

Assessment.Problem: Acute leg pain, onset this morning, without clear traumatic injury.
Assessment.Differential_Diagnosis_Considerations: Musculoskeletal pain (e.g., muscle strain, overuse), mechanical joint issue, inflammatory process (less likely given no swelling/bruising), or other causes of leg pain with activity.
Assessment.Current_Status: Pain is present with ambulation, no red flags identified so far (no compound fracture, loss of sensation/pulse, inability to move limb after major trauma).

Diagnostics_Needed: Further characterization of pain (ache, sharp, throbbing, stiffness).
Identification of specific location of pain (muscle, joint, bone).
Assessment of pain's impact on walking distance/limitation.
Confirm ability to move leg and joints (ankle, knee, hip) through full range of motion without significant pain.
Plan.Follow_up: Continue to gather details on pain characteristics and functional limitations.
